reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Very good book
reviews.reviewText: It took me reading one half of the book before it got interesting for me. But after that it took off. Was twists and turns galore, it is a page turner for sure. In the end, nothing that I thought or imagined would be the end result was true. If you start reading this book and find the first several chapters boring or not interesting, I encourage you to keep turning the pages. It does get interesting enough that you do not want to put the book down.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars I really wanted to rave about this book but some things just don’t add up *SPOILERS AHEAD*
reviews.reviewText: This book was riveting from the onset. Right away I fell straight into the story. I was rooting for Victoria’s innocence and cheering for Avery and Walt to clear her name.So many tiny things bother me. First we get Victoria telling us about how she killed Charlie but we don’t figure out htf she made it out of the north tower alive from above the impact zone? Also on this topic I thought no one made it out alive past the impact zone because it was so hot and smoky and all the exits were cut off because of the fires raging inside that there was no hope for those above the area of impact and that it was the south tower that hit at more of an angle and allowed for a better chance of escape?Never mind the detail though I can suspend reality for a moment but why don’t we hear about Victoria from that day? And did she pull her own tooth out? How did she lose the tooth? When she begin to plot this whole new life thing and also she had the forethought to plead her non existent innocent as she faced the possibility of dying?I’m still not over the tooth. How did she lose the tooth? And how did she make it out? The main tension of the story was beautiful but these random straws suddenly thrown in at the end like her brother being alive and how that just suddenly appeared and concluded and also we never see the closure w her father - why did she never have some kind of visit or something w her dad ?I’m slightly disappointed by the last 20 or so pages

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Great story didn't see that coming. This is my first book by this author, definitely looking to read more by him.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars wow! page turner!
reviews.reviewText: One of the best books I have read in months. Kept me turning pages into the night and new twist turning up in every chapter. Read this book! You will not want to put it down.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2023
reviews.reviewText: When I first started this book I wasn’t sure I was going to enjoy it because just like the other book I read from Charlie the medical jargon and police procedural was a lot to get through. But I enjoyed the mystery so much and the characters that the jargon took a backseat and didn’t bother me like the last time.The story opens up with a death in the Catskills in the summer of 2001 where new detective Walt Jenkins has been assigned to the case. Famous author Cameron Young has been found naked hanging from a second-story balcony. Is it murder or suicide? We’re then taken to Sept 11, 2001, in the Twin Towers where Victoria Ford who is accused of killing her married lover Cameron is meeting with her attorney minutes before one of the planes hit.Twenty years later the medical examiners' office is still working on identifying victims from 9-11 using new technology when there is a discovery of a fragment that DNA says belongs to Victoria Ford.Avery Mason is a news anchor who is looking for a new hook to secure her position and new contract when she hears about this discovery. She knows there’s a story and decides to chase it. While chasing the story she stumbles on a mystery when Victorias' sister has her listen to a voicemail Victoria left her on 9-11 proclaiming her innocence. Between trying to figure out what happened to Cameron and dealing with her family drama Avery finds herself working alongside former detective Walt Jenkins who has some secrets of his own.This was a book that was so hard to put down once I got into it because of the two big mysteries I just had to solve. There is definitely a lot going on in this book but I found the storyline so intriguing that it didn’t deter me from finishing or enjoying it. I also can appreciate that just when I thought I had it all figured out there was another twist that proved me wrong. If you’re looking for a fun mystery with a dabble of romance this is the book for you!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars TWENTY YEARS LATER, proving crime has no expiration date
reviews.reviewText: This novel is highly satisfying by combining the usual thriller components with twist after twist. The main characters have flaws while still likeable. Feel challenged as a reader in determining who the real murderer is as it is not obvious, nor is it a fringe character. The general storyline is enjoyable too.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars intriguing but some lacking qualities
reviews.reviewText: This was an enjoyable book that had some writers quirks that bothered me. The writer jumped between characters (which I like) but would spend two or three paragraphs repeating what had just happened in the characters prior chapters. It was a little annoying as I was actively reading the book and was well aware of the actions of the book.It is a new twist on the 9/11 tragedy, without going into the tragedy greatly however I think inserting a fictional character into this mass event can be off putting for some people. As a person who is fairly removed from the tragedy, I can enjoy the piece of fiction but I can see where it would be insensitive to others who experienced the tragedy more directly. There is some large scale name dropping (such as the OJ Simpson trial) that can be easily researched and proved that these characters aren’t real. That would be a large sticking point to consumers of true crime who know all the details to see a fictional character be tangentially related to cultural changing events with no ability to verify it.An enjoyable read for me but I can see where this piece of work would not be suitable for all readers and could become a polarizing piece of work

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This was soooooo good and is definitely severely underrated. The Mystery/Thriller genre is one of my favorites, but I often find I can figure out “whodunnit” within the first quarter of the book. Twenty Years Later had me thinking I had it all figured out, only to have Charlie Donlea completely and utterly rip the rug out from under me. And right when you think you got the big twist, it’s not over! This was the first book I’ve read by Donlea and it certainly will not be the last! How have I not seen anyone talking about this book?!

reviews.reviewTitle: Twenty Years Later by Charlie Donlea
reviews.reviewText: 🔅 𝑻𝒘𝒆𝒏𝒕𝒚 𝒀𝒆𝒂𝒓𝒔 𝑳𝒂𝒕𝒆𝒓 𝒃𝒚 𝑪𝒉𝒂𝒓𝒍𝒊𝒆 𝑫𝒐𝒏𝒍𝒆𝒂Genre: ThrillerRating: 5🌟𝐒𝐮𝐦𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐲:Avery Mason, host of American Events, knows the subjects that grab a TV audience’s attention. Her latest story—a murder mystery laced with kinky sex, tragedy, and betrayal—is guaranteed to be ratings gold. New DNA technology has allowed the New York medical examiner’s office to make its first successful identification of a 9/11 victim in years. The twist: the victim, Victoria Ford, had been accused of the gruesome murder of her married lover. In a chilling last phone call to her sister, Victoria begged her to prove her innocence. But the twisted puzzle of Victoria’s life just the beginning. And what Avery doesn’t realize is that there are other players in the game who are interested in Avery’s own secret past—one she has kept hidden from both the network executives and her television audience. A secret she thought was dead and buried…𝐌𝐲 𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐮𝐠𝐡𝐭𝐬:I absolutely loved this book. The storyline was captivating and Charlie Donlea’s writing was excellent. This was my first Charlie Donlea book and it made me fall in love with his style. I loved it so much that I’ve now read every single book he’s written. I love how this story follows multiple timelines and keeps you guessing. And the twist was *chef’s kiss*!

I really enjoyed this book.Initially I thought it was not going to be to my liking when it set the scene. However, it got me in and throughout the book I kept thinking about the different scenarios and what really happened. Of course, there was a twist and great twist.First time I have by Charlie Donlea and I will certainly look forward to reading other books written by him.
The plot is well crafted, but at times I found it too slow and was almost tempted to skip ahead. Liked the last chapters in the book, the twists were nice.

reviews.reviewTitle: WOW! Twist after twist after twist.
reviews.reviewText: This book was SO good. It lived up to all the hype I’ve seen in my various bookish circles. Just when I thought I had it figured out, I was hit with another twist. It kept me guessing until the absolute last page. So happy to have started my year with this one.
